title: 010 Connecting and Logging Into a FTP Server
To start using FTP with Java, you will need to create a new
FTPClient
c
and then connect and login to the server using
.connect(String server, int port)
c
and
.login(String username, String password)
c

inline_content.Text: To start using FTP with Java, you will need to create a new
FTPClient
and then connect and login to the server using
.connect(String server, int port)
and
.login(String username, String password)

title: Now we have the basics done. But what if we have an error connecting to the server? We’ll want to know when something goes wrong and get the error message. Let’s add some code to catch errors while connecting.

inline_content.Text: Now we have the basics done. But what if we have an error connecting to the server? We’ll want to know when something goes wrong and get the error message. Let’s add some code to catch errors while connecting.

title: Let’s break down what we just did, step by step.

inline_content.Text: Let’s break down what we just did, step by step.

title: showServerReply(ftp);
This refers to a function we will be making in a later step.

inline_content.Text: This refers to a function we will be making in a later step.

title: int replyCode = ftp.getReplyCode();
This grabs the reply/error code from the server and stores it as an integer.

inline_content.Text: This grabs the reply/error code from the server and stores it as an integer.

title: This checks the reply code to see if there was an error. If there was an error, it will simply print “Operation failed. Server reply code: “ followed by the error code. We also added a try/catch block which we will add to in the next step. Next, let’s also create a function that checks
ftp.login()
c
for errors.

inline_content.Text: This checks the reply code to see if there was an error. If there was an error, it will simply print “Operation failed. Server reply code: “ followed by the error code. We also added a try/catch block which we will add to in the next step. Next, let’s also create a function that checks
ftp.login()
for errors.

title: Let’s break this block down too.

inline_content.Text: Let’s break this block down too.

title: boolean success = ftp.login(user, pass);
This will not just attempt to login to the FTP server, it will also store the result as a boolean.

inline_content.Text: This will not just attempt to login to the FTP server, it will also store the result as a boolean.

title: showServerReply(ftp);
This will check if the server sent us any messages, but we will first need to create the function in the next step.

inline_content.Text: This will check if the server sent us any messages, but we will first need to create the function in the next step.

title: This statement will check if we logged in successfully; if so, it will print “LOGGED IN SERVER”, otherwise it will print “Failed to log into the server”. This is our script so far:

inline_content.Text: This statement will check if we logged in successfully; if so, it will print “LOGGED IN SERVER”, otherwise it will print “Failed to log into the server”. This is our script so far:

title: Now next let’s create complete the Catch block in case we run into any errors with the whole process.

inline_content.Text: Now next let’s create complete the Catch block in case we run into any errors with the whole process.

title: The completed catch block will now print “Oops! Something went wrong.” and the stacktrace if there is an error. Now our final step is to create the
showServerReply()
c
we have been using for a while now.

inline_content.Text: The completed catch block will now print “Oops! Something went wrong.” and the stacktrace if there is an error. Now our final step is to create the
showServerReply()
we have been using for a while now.

title: This function takes an
FTPClient
c

as a variable, and calls it “ftp”. After that it stores any server replies from the server in a string array. Next it checks if any messages were stored. If there is any, it prints each of them as “SERVER: [reply]”. Now that we have that function done, this is the completed script:

inline_content.Text: This function takes an
FTPClient

as a variable, and calls it “ftp”. After that it stores any server replies from the server in a string array. Next it checks if any messages were stored. If there is any, it prints each of them as “SERVER: [reply]”. Now that we have that function done, this is the completed script:

title: We first need to create a new
FTPClient
c
and try connecting to the server it and logging into it using
.connect(String server, int port)
c
and
.login(String username, String password)
c

. It is important to connect and login using a try/catch block in case our code fails to connect with the server. We will also need to create a function that checks and displays any messages we may receive from the server as we try connecting and logging in. We will call this function “
showServerReply(FTPClient ftp)
c

inline_content.Text: We first need to create a new
FTPClient
and try connecting to the server it and logging into it using
.connect(String server, int port)
and
.login(String username, String password)

. It is important to connect and login using a try/catch block in case our code fails to connect with the server. We will also need to create a function that checks and displays any messages we may receive from the server as we try connecting and logging in. We will call this function “
showServerReply(FTPClient ftp)

title: After this, you should now have your FTP server connected to you Java script.

inline_content.Text: After this, you should now have your FTP server connected to you Java script.
